After the end of the Mau Mau rebellion, Itote became involved in politics and was elected to the Kenyan parliament in 1969. He remained a prominent figure in Kenyan politics until his death in 1995.

Itote is remembered as a hero in Kenya for his role in the fight for independence, and he is often cited as an inspiration for subsequent generations of Kenyan nationalists and freedom fighters.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Anna May Wong.

answers.answer:
Anna May Wong was a pioneering Chinese-American actress who achieved international fame during the early 20th century. Born in Los Angeles in 1905, Wong began acting in films at the age of 17 and quickly established herself as one of Hollywood's most talented and versatile actresses. She appeared in over 60 films, playing both lead and supporting roles, and was known for her beauty, elegance, and charisma on screen.

Despite her success, Wong faced discrimination and racism throughout her career. She was often relegated to playing stereotypical "exotic" characters and was frequently passed over for leading roles in favor of white actresses. Wong also faced backlash from the Chinese-American community, who criticized her for perpetuating negative stereotypes.

Despite these challenges, Wong continued to work in the film industry until her death in 1961. She remains an important figure in the history of Hollywood and Asian-American representation in film.

She had a successful film career in Hollywood and Europe, making over 40 films and appearing in numerous television shows throughout her career. She is best known for her roles in Piccadilly (1929), The Toll of the Sea (1922), Shanghai Express (1932), and Daughter of the Dragon (1931). Wong was an outspoken advocate for Asian-American representation in Hollywood, and was a powerful figure in the fight against racism and sexism in the entertainment industry. Her legacy as a pioneering actress and advocate continues to this day.

She was born Wong Liu Tsong on January 3, 1905, in Los Angeles, California, one block north of Chinatown[1][2]. Her father exposed his family to the creative arts and often took them to see traditional Chinese stage productions. Young Anna was fascinated by the emerging film industry in the area and dreamed of becoming a movie actress like Pearl White or Mary Pickford[2].

Wong's acting career spanned silent film, sound film, television, stage, and radio[1]. She worked during an era when East Asian Americans were cast in a negative light and often played by non-East Asian actors who used yellow make-up on their skin and tape on their eyelids to mimic what the industry believed passed as Asian facial features[2]. Despite having starring lead roles in films such as "The Toll of the Sea" (1922), "Piccadilly" (1929), and "Shanghai Express" (1932), she felt stereotyped and limited in the United States[2].

In 1937, Wong starred in "Daughter of Shanghai," a crime film directed by Robert Florey that featured East Asian American actors playing lead roles. It was one of the first films to do so at that time[3]. In 2020, Michelle Krusiec played Anna May Wong in Ryan Murphy's Netflix series "Hollywood"[4].

question: Question: Tell me a bio of James B. Donovan.

answers.answer:
James B. Donovan was an American lawyer who was born on February 29, 1916, in New York City. He graduated from Fordham University Law School in 1941 and served in the United States Navy during World War II. After the war, he worked as an assistant district attorney in New York City and then went into private practice.

Donovan is best known for his work as a defense attorney for accused Soviet spy Rudolf Abel in 1957. Despite public opinion being against him, Donovan vigorously defended Abel and secured a sentence of 30 years instead of the death penalty. In 1962, Donovan played a key role in negotiating the release of American pilot Francis Gary Powers from the Soviet Union after his U-2 spy plane was shot down.

Donovan was also involved in the early stages of the Cuban Missile Crisis, serving as a back-channel negotiator between the United States and the Soviet Union. He was later awarded the Medal of Freedom by President Lyndon B. Johnson for his efforts.

Donovan died on January 19, 1970, in Brooklyn, New York. He is remembered as a skilled and dedicated lawyer, as well as a tireless defender of civil liberties and human rights.

He is also remembered for his involvement in the Nuremberg Trials, the creation of the International Refugee Organization, and his successful defense of accused Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann. question: Question: Tell me a bio of George Cukor.

He was also a mentor to many young filmmakers who went on to become successful in their own right.

Cukor passed away on January 24, 1983, in Beverly Hills, California, leaving behind a legacy of critically acclaimed films and a reputation as one of the greatest directors in Hollywood history.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of António de Oliveira Salazar.

answers.answer:
António de Oliveira Salazar was a Portuguese politician and economist who served as the Prime Minister of Portugal from 1932 to 1968. Born in 1889 in Vimieiro, Portugal, he studied law and economics at the University of Coimbra before becoming a professor and later the Minister of Finance in 1928. 

During his time as Prime Minister, Salazar implemented a conservative and authoritarian regime, known as the Estado Novo, which emphasized traditional values, centralization of power, and economic development. He also established a secret police force, censorship of the press, and suppression of political opposition. 

Salazar's policies helped modernize Portugal and improve its economy, particularly through infrastructure development and promotion of industry. However, his regime was also criticized for its human rights violations and lack of political freedom. 

Salazar's health declined in the 1960s and he was replaced as Prime Minister in 1968. He died in 1970, leaving behind a complicated legacy as a controversial figure in Portuguese history.

António de Oliveira Salazar was a Portuguese statesman who served as Prime Minister of Portugal from 1932 to 1968. He was born in 1889 in the small town of Vimieiro, in the municipality of Santa Comba in northern Portugal. He was a devout Roman Catholic and a highly educated man, having studied law at the University of Coimbra and economics at the University of Paris. His economic policies, often referred to as "Salazarism," sought to protect Portuguese sovereignty and maintain a low debt-to-GDP ratio. Under Salazar, Portugal was largely isolationist, refusing to join the League of Nations or the United Nations. Salazar's regime was marked by authoritarianism, with censorship, the suppression of civil liberties, and the use of secret police and torture. He was overthrown in a 1974 military coup. He died in 1970 at the age of 81.

He became a professor of economics at the University of Coimbra in 1928 and was appointed Minister of Finance in 1928[1].

Salazar's early reforms and policies allowed political and financial stability, social order, and economic growth after the politically unstable and financially chaotic years of the Portuguese First Republic[2]. However, his regime was also characterized by censorship, repression, and human rights abuses[2].

Salazar's rule ended in 1968 when he suffered a stroke that left him incapacitated. Marcelo Caetano succeeded him as Prime Minister but could not hide the obvious dictatorship that oppressed Portugal[2]. Salazar died two years later in Lisbon at the age of 81[1].

Salazar has been described as "by far the world's best dictator" by some scholars[3]. His legacy is still debated today, with some seeing him as a hero who saved Portugal from chaos while others view him as a tyrant who suppressed freedom and democracy[2].

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Egon Krenz.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Heinrich Harrer.

Harrer was interned in a British POW camp in India, but he escaped and eventually made his way to Tibet, where he lived for seven years.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Robert Louis Stevenson.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of José Sánchez del Río.

José Sánchez del Río was a Mexican Cristero who was born on March 28, 1913, in Sahuayo, Michoacán, Mexico. He became a member of the Cristero army during the Cristero War, which was a rebellion against the Mexican government's persecution of the Roman Catholic Church.

At the age of 14, José joined the Cristero army, where he served as a flag bearer. He was known for his bravery and dedication to the cause, and he quickly became a respected member of the army.

In 1928, José was captured by the Mexican government and was brutally tortured for refusing to renounce his faith. Despite the torture, he remained steadfast in his beliefs and refused to give in to the government's demands.

On February 10, 1928, José was executed by the government at the age of 14. His execution was a turning point in the Cristero War and helped to inspire others to continue the fight for religious freedom.

José Sánchez del Río was canonized as a saint by the Catholic Church on October 16, 2016. He is remembered as a martyr and a hero of the Cristero War.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Paul Kruger.

Paul Kruger was a South African politician and military leader who served as the President of the South African Republic from 1883 to 1900. He was born on 10 October 1825 in the Cape Colony (now South Africa) and grew up in the rural Eastern Cape. Kruger was a prominent figure in the Boer War (1899-1902), leading the Boers in their defense against the British Empire.

Kruger was a staunch believer in Boer independence and was instrumental in securing the Transvaal's independence from British rule in 1881. He was known for his strong leadership and his deep commitment to the Afrikaner cause. Kruger was also a deeply religious man and was heavily influenced by his Christian faith.

Kruger's presidency was marked by several challenges, including economic instability, political turmoil, and tensions with neighboring countries. He was also a controversial figure, criticized by some for his strict policies towards non-white South Africans and his role in the Second Boer War.

Kruger died on 14 July 1904 in Clarens, Switzerland, while in exile. Despite his controversial legacy, he remains an important figure in South African history and is widely recognized as a symbol of Afrikaner nationalism and resistance against British imperialism.

Kruger is a controversial figure; admirers venerate him as a tragic folk hero.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Anushka Sharma.

Anushka Sharma is an Indian actress and film producer. She was born on May 1, 1988, in Ayodhya, Uttar Pradesh, India. She began her career in the entertainment industry as a model and made her acting debut in the 2008 film "Rab Ne Bana Di Jodi" opposite Shah Rukh Khan. 

Since then, Anushka has appeared in numerous successful Bollywood films such as "Band Baaja Baaraat", "PK", "Sultan", "Ae Dil Hai Mushkil", and "Sanju". She is also a film producer and has produced critically acclaimed projects such as "NH10", "Phillauri", and "Pari" under her production company, Clean Slate Films.

Anushka has received several awards for her performances in films, including a Filmfare Award for Best Supporting Actress for "Jab Tak Hai Jaan" and a Filmfare Award for Best Actress for "Sultan". She is known for her versatility as an actress and her strong on-screen presence.

She is one of the most popular and highest-paid actresses in India. She has appeared in Forbes India's Celebrity 100 list since 2012 and was featured by Forbes Asia in their 30 Under 30 list of 2018.

Her father, Colonel Ajay Kumar Sharma, is an army officer, and her mother, Ashima Sharma, is a homemaker. Anushka Sharma's grandmother Urmila still lives in Dehradun town of Uttarakhand on Naishvilla road where her father lived before joining the Indian army [1].

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Rakhi Sawant.

She has also been involved in various social and charitable causes, including supporting acid attack victims and advocating for animal rights.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of IU (singer).

answers.answer:
IU is a popular South Korean singer, songwriter and actress. She was born on May 16, 1993 in Gwangju, South Korea. Her real name is Lee Ji-eun. She began her singing career at a young age and gained popularity in 2010 with her hit song "Good Day". 

IU has released numerous albums and singles throughout her career and has won many awards, including multiple Melon Music Awards, Golden Disc Awards, and Seoul Music Awards. She is known for her sweet and soulful voice, and her ability to write and compose her own songs.

Aside from her music career, IU has also acted in several popular Korean dramas, such as "Dream High" and "Hotel Del Luna". She is considered one of the most successful and influential artists in the Korean music industry, and has a huge following both in South Korea and internationally.

Since then, she has released numerous albums and singles, including "Good Day," "You & I," "The Red Shoes," "Palette," and "Love Poem." She has also collaborated with numerous artists, including BTS, Zion.T, and Suga of BTS. IU is a multi-talented artist, having starred in numerous dramas, films, and variety shows. She has also won multiple awards, including the Grand Prize at the Mnet Asian Music Awards and the Best Female Artist award at the Golden Disc Awards.

During her middle school years, IU discovered her passion for singing and decided to become a singer after being applauded for a performance she gave at her school's sports competition[1].

IU began her career in the entertainment industry as a trainee under LOEN Entertainment in 2007. She moved to Bangbae, Seoul after signing with the company[1]. question: Question: Tell me a bio of Taika Waititi.

answers.answer:
Taika Waititi is a New Zealand filmmaker, actor, and comedian. He was born on August 16, 1975, in Wellington, New Zealand. Waititi began his career as a comedian and actor in the late 1990s, performing in various comedy troupes and television shows. He later gained international recognition as a filmmaker with his acclaimed 2014 movie "What We Do in the Shadows," a mockumentary about a group of vampires living together in modern-day New Zealand. 

Waititi's other notable films include "Hunt for the Wilderpeople," a coming-of-age comedy-drama, and "Thor: Ragnarok," the third installment in the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Thor series, which he directed and also appeared in as the character Korg. In 2019, Waititi won the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay for his film "Jojo Rabbit," a satirical black comedy-drama set in Nazi Germany during World War II. 

Waititi is also known for his work in television, having directed episodes of "Flight of the Conchords," "The Inbetweeners," and "The Mandalorian." He has also made appearances in popular television shows such as "Breaking Bad" and "Rick and Morty."

Taika Waititi (born August 16, 1975) is a New Zealand filmmaker, actor, writer and comedian. He was nominated for an Academy Award for his 2004 short film Two Cars, One Night. He is best known for directing the films Boy (2010), What We Do in the Shadows (2014), Hunt for the Wilderpeople (2016), Thor: Ragnarok (2017), and Jojo Rabbit (2019). He has also starred in the films Eagle vs Shark (2007), Boy (2010), and Hunt for the Wilderpeople (2016). Waititi's work is often characterized by its sense of humor, quirkiness, and deadpan delivery. He is of Te-Whanau-a-Apanui and Jewish descent.

Taika Waititi, born Taika David Cohen on August 16, 1975, is a New Zealand filmmaker, actor and comedian. He has won several awards including an Academy Award, a BAFTA Award and a Grammy Award[1]. He graduated from Victoria University of Wellington with a Bachelor of Arts degree[1]. His feature films Boy (2010) and Hunt for the Wilderpeople (2016) have each been the top-grossing New Zealand film[1]. In addition to his work in film, he has also directed episodes of television shows such as The Mandalorian and What We Do in the Shadows[1].

Waititi frequently collaborates with other New Zealand actors and filmmakers. Rachel House has acted in four of his films: Eagle vs Shark, Boy, Hunt for the Wilderpeople and Thor: Ragnarok[2]. Jemaine Clement co-wrote, co-directed and co-starred with Waititi in What We Do in the Shadows (2014)[5].

Waititi's most recent film is Jojo Rabbit (2019), which he wrote and directed. The film won the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay[3]. Time magazine named him one of the 100 most influential people in the world on its annual list in 2022[1].

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Kang Daniel.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Tim Fischer.

answers.answer: Tim Fischer was an Australian politician, diplomat, and farmer who was born on May 3, 1946, and passed away on August 22, 2019. He was the leader of the National Party of Australia from 1990 to 1999, and served as the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade in the Howard Government from 1996 to 1999. Fischer was also known for his advocacy for gun control after the 1996 Port Arthur massacre, and for his work to improve the quality of life for regional Australians. After leaving politics, he served as Australia's Ambassador to the Holy See from 2008 to 2012. Prior to his political career, Fischer served in the Australian Army and worked as a farmer.

Tim Fischer (born 3 May 1946) is an Australian politician and diplomat. He is a former Deputy Prime Minister of Australia and leader of the National Party from 1990 to 1999. He was a Member of the House of Representatives for the electoral division of Farrer from 1984 to 2001. He was appointed Australia's Ambassador to the Holy See in 2008 and held this post until 2012. He was Deputy Prime Minister in the Howard Government from 1996 to 1999, and served as the Minister for Trade from 1996 to 1998. He was also the Minister for Transport and Regional Development from 1998 to 1999. Fischer was born in Lockhart, New South Wales, and later studied at the University of New England, Armidale, where he completed a Bachelor of Arts in Public Policy and Administration. He has since been awarded honorary doctorates from the University of New England and the University of Western Sydney. He is a passionate advocate of rail transport, and is the author of Aussie Logistics: The Train Journey of a Nation.

question: Question: Tell me a bio of Dacre Montgomery.
